snippet.textDisplay:
Clearcoat is like a layer of extra material painted over a surface - just like a varnish. And just like a varnish, that can indeed have absorption, e.g. a dark brown all the way through to crystal clear, depending on the material being used as the coat. If you paint over a light wood with a heavy dark brown varnish, then all aspects of the light wood (its diffuse and its reflection etc) will become colored by how the top layer absorbs light - which is what happens here.

Clearcoat is not required for colored metals, anything set to Metal has its color controls (non-Metals always reflect white, so there are no color controls for reflection there... unless you add a clearcoat on top, again like the wood, the reflection of light there would be white, unless that is passing through a colored varnish).

Thanks!
  Tom
